title: Quiz 9: Neonatal Emergencies
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Neonatal resuscitation, birth asphyxia, and emergency neonatal care

questions.question: What is the Apgar score at 1 minute for a newborn who is not breathing, has no heart rate, is limp, blue, and has no response to stimulation?
questions.explanation: An Apgar score of 0 indicates severe depression. This newborn would score 0 for all five criteria: Appearance (blue), Pulse (no heart rate), Grimace (no response), Activity (limp), and Respiration (not breathing).
questions.hint: Each of the 5 criteria is scored 0-2, so the minimum is 0.

questions.question: What is the first step in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.explanation: The first step in neonatal resuscitation is drying and stimulating the baby while providing warmth. This simple intervention often triggers spontaneous breathing in depressed newborns.
questions.hint: This is the most basic and immediate intervention.

questions.question: Positive pressure ventilation (PPV) is indicated if the baby is not breathing or has a heart rate below 100 bpm after initial stimulation.
questions.explanation: True. Positive pressure ventilation is the most important intervention in neonatal resuscitation and is indicated if the baby is not breathing or has a heart rate below 100 bpm after initial drying and stimulation.
questions.hint: This is the primary intervention for respiratory support.

questions.question: Which of the following are indications for chest compressions in neonatal resuscitation? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Heart rate remains below 60 bpm after effective PPV
No heart rate detected after 30 seconds of PPV

questions.explanation: Chest compressions are indicated if the heart rate remains below 60 bpm despite effective positive pressure ventilation for 30 seconds. They are not indicated for heart rates above 60 bpm or for apnea alone.
questions.hint: This is a more advanced intervention for severe bradycardia.

questions.question: Match each resuscitation step with its correct action:
questions.explanation: Initial steps = dry, stimulate, provide warmth; Ventilation = positive pressure ventilation; Chest compressions = if HR < 60 after PPV; Medications = epinephrine if HR < 60 after compressions. This is the sequential approach.
questions.hint: Follow the order from basic to advanced interventions.

questions.question: The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio for neonatal resuscitation is ___BLANK___ compressions to ___BLANK___ ventilations.
questions.explanation: The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio for neonatal resuscitation is 3:1. This is different from the 30:2 ratio used for adult CPR because newborns primarily need ventilation support.
questions.hint: This ratio is specific to newborns.

questions.question: What is the definition of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)?

options.text: Brain injury due to lack of oxygen and blood flow
Brain injury due to metabolic disorders

questions.explanation: Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is brain injury caused by inadequate oxygen supply (hypoxia) and reduced blood flow (ischemia) to the brain, typically occurring around the time of birth.
questions.hint: The name describes the two main causes: lack of oxygen and blood flow.

questions.question: What is the treatment for moderate to severe HIE within 6 hours of birth?
questions.explanation: Therapeutic hypothermia (whole-body cooling to 33.5Â°C for 72 hours) initiated within 6 hours of birth is the standard treatment for moderate to severe HIE. It reduces brain injury and improves neurological outcomes.
questions.hint: This treatment involves cooling the baby.

questions.question: Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs when the baby inhales meconium-stained amniotic fluid into the lungs before or during birth.
questions.explanation: True. Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs when the baby inhales meconium-stained amniotic fluid into the lungs before or during birth. It can cause respiratory distress, pneumonitis, and persistent pulmonary hypertension.
questions.hint: This involves the baby's first bowel movement (meconium) getting into the lungs.

questions.question: What is the primary indication for administering epinephrine in neonatal resuscitation?
questions.explanation: Epinephrine is indicated in neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 bpm despite effective positive pressure ventilation and chest compressions for at least 30-45 seconds.
questions.hint: This is used when the heart rate is critically low despite other interventions.
